     9→
    10→package org.elasticsearch;
    11→
    12→import org.elasticsearch.common.VersionId;
    13→import org.elasticsearch.common.io.stream.StreamInput;
    14→import org.elasticsearch.common.io.stream.StreamOutput;
    15→import org.elasticsearch.internal.VersionExtension;
    16→import org.elasticsearch.plugins.ExtensionLoader;
    17→
    18→import java.io.IOException;
    19→import java.util.ServiceLoader;
    20→
    21→/**
    22→ * Represents the version of the wire protocol used to communicate between a pair of ES nodes.
    23→ * <p>
    24→ * Prior to 8.8.0, the release {@link Version} was used everywhere. This class separates the wire protocol version from the release version.
    25→ * <p>
    26→ * Each transport version constant has an id number, which for versions prior to 8.9.0 is the same as the release version for backwards
    27→ * compatibility. In 8.9.0 this is changed to an incrementing number, disconnected from the release version.
    28→ * <p>
    29→ * Each version constant has a unique id string. This is not actually used in the binary protocol, but is there to ensure each protocol
    30→ * version is only added to the source file once. This string needs to be unique (normally a UUID, but can be any other unique nonempty
    31→ * string). If two concurrent PRs add the same transport version, the different unique ids cause a git conflict, ensuring that the second PR
    32→ * to be merged must be updated with the next free version first. Without the unique id string, git will happily merge the two versions
    33→ * together, resulting in the same transport version being used across multiple commits, causing problems when you try to upgrade between
    34→ * those two merged commits.
    35→ *
    36→ * <h2>Version compatibility</h2>
    37→ * The earliest compatible version is hardcoded in the {@link TransportVersions#MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE} field. Previously, this was dynamically
    38→ * calculated from the major/minor versions of {@link Version}, but {@code TransportVersion} does not have separate major/minor version
    39→ * numbers. So the minimum compatible version is hard-coded as the transport version used by the highest minor release of the previous
    40→ * major version. {@link TransportVersions#MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE} should be updated appropriately whenever a major release happens.
    41→ * <p>
    42→ * The earliest CCS compatible version is hardcoded at {@link TransportVersions#MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION}, as the transport version used by the
    43→ * previous minor release. This should be updated appropriately whenever a minor release happens.
    44→ *
    45→ * <h2>Scope of usefulness of {@link TransportVersion}</h2>
    46→ * {@link TransportVersion} is a property of the transport connection between a pair of nodes, and should not be used as an indication of
    47→ * the version of any single node. The {@link TransportVersion} of a connection is negotiated between the nodes via some logic that is not
    48→ * totally trivial, and may change in future. Any other places that might make decisions based on this version effectively have to reproduce
    49→ * this negotiation logic, which would be fragile. If you need to make decisions based on the version of a single node, do so using a
    50→ * different version value. If you need to know whether the cluster as a whole speaks a new enough {@link TransportVersion} to understand a
    51→ * newly-added feature, use {@link org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterState#getMinTransportVersion}.
    52→ */
    53→public record TransportVersion(int id) implements VersionId<TransportVersion> {
    54→
    55→    public static TransportVersion readVersion(StreamInput in) throws IOException {
    56→        return fromId(in.readVInt());
    57→    }
    58→
    59→    public static TransportVersion fromId(int id) {
    60→        TransportVersion known = TransportVersions.VERSION_IDS.get(id);
    61→        if (known != null) {
    62→            return known;
    63→        }
    64→        // this is a version we don't otherwise know about - just create a placeholder
    65→        return new TransportVersion(id);
    66→    }
    67→
    68→    public static void writeVersion(TransportVersion version, StreamOutput out) throws IOException {
    69→        out.writeVInt(version.id);
    70→    }
    71→
    72→    /**
    73→     * Returns the minimum version of {@code version1} and {@code version2}
    74→     */
    75→    public static TransportVersion min(TransportVersion version1, TransportVersion version2) {
    76→        return version1.id < version2.id ? version1 : version2;
    77→    }
    78→
    79→    /**
    80→     * Returns the maximum version of {@code version1} and {@code version2}
    81→     */
    82→    public static TransportVersion max(TransportVersion version1, TransportVersion version2) {
    83→        return version1.id > version2.id ? version1 : version2;
    84→    }
    85→
    86→    /**
    87→     * Returns {@code true} if the specified version is compatible with this running version of Elasticsearch.
    88→     */
    89→    public static boolean isCompatible(TransportVersion version) {
    90→        return version.onOrAfter(TransportVersions.MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE);
    91→    }
    92→
    93→    /**
    94→     * Reference to the most recent transport version.
    95→     * This should be the transport version with the highest id.
    96→     */
    97→    public static TransportVersion current() {
    98→        return CurrentHolder.CURRENT;
    99→    }
   100→
   101→    public static TransportVersion fromString(String str) {
   102→        return TransportVersion.fromId(Integer.parseInt(str));
   103→    }
   104→
   105→    /**
   106→     * Returns {@code true} if this version is a patch version at or after {@code version}.
   107→     * <p>
   108→     * This should not be used normally. It is used for matching patch versions of the same base version,
   109→     * using the standard version number format specified in {@link TransportVersions}.
   110→     * When a patch version of an existing transport version is created, {@code transportVersion.isPatchFrom(patchVersion)}
   111→     * will match any transport version at or above {@code patchVersion} that is also of the same base version.
   112→     * <p>
   113→     * For example, {@code version.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)} will return the following for the given {@code version}:
   114→     * <ul>
   115→     *     <li>{@code 8_799_00_0.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code false}</li>
   116→     *     <li>{@code 8_799_00_9.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code false}</li>
   117→     *     <li>{@code 8_800_00_0.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code false}</li>
   118→     *     <li>{@code 8_800_00_3.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code false}</li>
   119→     *     <li>{@code 8_800_00_4.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code true}</li>
   120→     *     <li>{@code 8_800_00_9.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code true}</li>
   121→     *     <li>{@code 8_800_01_0.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code false}</li>
   122→     *     <li>{@code 8_801_00_0.isPatchFrom(8_800_00_4)}: {@code false}</li>
   123→     * </ul>
   124→     */
   125→    public boolean isPatchFrom(TransportVersion version) {
   126→        return onOrAfter(version) && id < version.id + 10 - (version.id % 10);
   127→    }
   128→
   129→    /**
   130→     * Returns a string representing the Elasticsearch release version of this transport version,
   131→     * if applicable for this deployment, otherwise the raw version number.
   132→     */
   133→    public String toReleaseVersion() {
   134→        return TransportVersions.VERSION_LOOKUP.apply(id);
   135→    }
   136→
   137→    @Override
   138→    public String toString() {
   139→        return Integer.toString(id);
   140→    }
   141→
   142→    private static class CurrentHolder {
   143→        private static final TransportVersion CURRENT = findCurrent();
   144→
   145→        // finds the pluggable current version
   146→        private static TransportVersion findCurrent() {
   147→            var version = ExtensionLoader.loadSingleton(ServiceLoader.load(VersionExtension.class))
   148→                .map(e -> e.getCurrentTransportVersion(TransportVersions.LATEST_DEFINED))
   149→                .orElse(TransportVersions.LATEST_DEFINED);
   150→            assert version.onOrAfter(TransportVersions.LATEST_DEFINED);
   151→            return version;
   152→        }
   153→    }
   154→}

    10→package org.elasticsearch;

    12→import org.elasticsearch.core.Assertions;

    26→/**
    27→ * <p>Transport version is used to coordinate compatible wire protocol communication between nodes, at a fine-grained level.  This replaces
    28→ * and supersedes the old Version constants.</p>
    29→ *
    30→ * <p>Before adding a new version constant, please read the block comment at the end of the list of constants.</p>
    31→ */
    32→public class TransportVersions {

    34→    /*
    35→     * NOTE: IntelliJ lies!
    36→     * This map is used during class construction, referenced by the registerTransportVersion method.
    37→     * When all the transport version constants have been registered, the map is cleared & never touched again.
    38→     */
    39→    static TreeSet<Integer> IDS = new TreeSet<>();
    40→
    41→    static TransportVersion def(int id) {
    42→        if (IDS == null) throw new IllegalStateException("The IDS map needs to be present to call this method");
    43→
    44→        if (IDS.add(id) == false) {
    45→            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Version id " + id + " defined twice");
    46→        }
    47→        if (id < IDS.last()) {
    48→            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Version id " + id + " is not defined in the right location. Keep constants sorted");
    49→        }
    50→        return new TransportVersion(id);
    51→    }

   250→    /*
   251→     * STOP! READ THIS FIRST! No, really,
   252→     *        ____ _____ ___  ____  _        ____  _____    _    ____    _____ _   _ ___ ____    _____ ___ ____  ____ _____ _
   253→     *       / ___|_   _/ _ \|  _ \| |      |  _ \| ____|  / \  |  _ \  |_   _| | | |_ _/ ___|  |  ___|_ _|  _ \/ ___|_   _| |
   254→     *       \___ \ | || | | | |_) | |      | |_) |  _|   / _ \ | | | |   | | | |_| || |\___ \  | |_   | || |_) \___ \ | | | |
   255→     *        ___) || || |_| |  __/|_|      |  _ <| |___ / ___ \| |_| |   | | |  _  || | ___) | |  _|  | ||  _ < ___) || | |_|
   256→     *       |____/ |_| \___/|_|   (_)      |_| \_\_____/_/   \_\____/    |_| |_| |_|___|____/  |_|   |___|_| \_\____/ |_| (_)
   257→     *
   258→     * A new transport version should be added EVERY TIME a change is made to the serialization protocol of one or more classes. Each
   259→     * transport version should only be used in a single merged commit (apart from the BwC versions copied from o.e.Version, ≤V_8_8_1).
   260→     *
   261→     * ADDING A TRANSPORT VERSION
   262→     * To add a new transport version, add a new constant at the bottom of the list, above this comment. Don't add other lines,
   263→     * comments, etc. The version id has the following layout:
   264→     *
   265→     * M_NNN_SS_P
   266→     *
   267→     * M - The major version of Elasticsearch
   268→     * NNN - The server version part
   269→     * SS - The serverless version part. It should always be 00 here, it is used by serverless only.
   270→     * P - The patch version part
   271→     *
   272→     * To determine the id of the next TransportVersion constant, do the following:
   273→     * - Use the same major version, unless bumping majors
   274→     * - Bump the server version part by 1, unless creating a patch version
   275→     * - Leave the serverless part as 00
   276→     * - Bump the patch part if creating a patch version
   277→     *
   278→     * If a patch version is created, it should be placed sorted among the other existing constants.
   279→     *
   280→     * REVERTING A TRANSPORT VERSION
   281→     *
   282→     * If you revert a commit with a transport version change, you MUST ensure there is a NEW transport version representing the reverted
   283→     * change. DO NOT let the transport version go backwards, it must ALWAYS be incremented.
   284→     *
   285→     * DETERMINING TRANSPORT VERSIONS FROM GIT HISTORY
   286→     *
   287→     * If your git checkout has the expected minor-version-numbered branches and the expected release-version tags then you can find the
   288→     * transport versions known by a particular release ...
   289→     *
   290→     *     git show v8.11.0:server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java | grep '= def'
   291→     *
   292→     * ... or by a particular branch ...
   293→     *
   294→     *     git show 8.11:server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java | grep '= def'
   295→     *
   296→     * ... and you can see which versions were added in between two versions too ...
   297→     *
   298→     *     git diff v8.11.0..main -- server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java
   299→     *
   300→     * In branches 8.7-8.10 see server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersion.java for the equivalent definitions.
   301→     */
   302→
   303→    /**
   304→     * Reference to the earliest compatible transport version to this version of the codebase.
   305→     * This should be the transport version used by the highest minor version of the previous major.
   306→     */
   307→    public static final TransportVersion MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE = V_7_17_0;
   308→

   310→     * Reference to the minimum transport version that can be used with CCS.
   311→     * This should be the transport version used by the previous minor release.
   312→     */
   313→    public static final TransportVersion MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION = ESQL_ATTRIBUTE_CACHED_SERIALIZATION_8_15;
   314→
   315→    static final NavigableMap<Integer, TransportVersion> VERSION_IDS = getAllVersionIds(TransportVersions.class);
   316→
   317→    // the highest transport version constant defined in this file, used as a fallback for TransportVersion.current()
   318→    static final TransportVersion LATEST_DEFINED;
   319→    static {
   320→        LATEST_DEFINED = VERSION_IDS.lastEntry().getValue();
   321→
   322→        // see comment on IDS field
   323→        // now we're registered all the transport versions, we can clear the map
   324→        IDS = null;
   325→    }
   326→
   327→    public static NavigableMap<Integer, TransportVersion> getAllVersionIds(Class<?> cls) {
   328→        Map<Integer, String> versionIdFields = new HashMap<>();
   329→        NavigableMap<Integer, TransportVersion> builder = new TreeMap<>();
   330→
   331→        Set<String> ignore = Set.of("ZERO", "CURRENT", "MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE", "MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION");
   332→
   333→        for (Field declaredField : cls.getFields()) {
   334→            if (declaredField.getType().equals(TransportVersion.class)) {
   335→                String fieldName = declaredField.getName();
   336→                if (ignore.contains(fieldName)) {
   337→                    continue;
   338→                }
   339→
   340→                TransportVersion version;
   341→                try {
   342→                    version = (TransportVersion) declaredField.get(null);
   343→                } catch (IllegalAccessException e) {
   344→                    throw new AssertionError(e);
   345→                }
   346→                builder.put(version.id(), version);
   347→
   348→                if (Assertions.ENABLED) {
   349→                    // check the version number is unique
   350→                    var sameVersionNumber = versionIdFields.put(version.id(), fieldName);
   351→                    assert sameVersionNumber == null
   352→                        : "Versions ["
   353→                            + sameVersionNumber
   354→                            + "] and ["
   355→                            + fieldName
   356→                            + "] have the same version number ["
   357→                            + version.id()
   358→                            + "]. Each TransportVersion should have a different version number";
   359→                }
   360→            }
   361→        }
   362→
   363→        return Collections.unmodifiableNavigableMap(builder);
   364→    }
   365→
   366→    static Collection<TransportVersion> getAllVersions() {
   367→        return VERSION_IDS.values();
   368→    }
   369→
   370→    static final IntFunction<String> VERSION_LOOKUP = ReleaseVersions.generateVersionsLookup(TransportVersions.class, LATEST_DEFINED.id());
   371→
   372→    // no instance
   373→    private TransportVersions() {}
   374→}

     9→
    10→package org.elasticsearch.cluster.service;
    11→
    12→import org.elasticsearch.TransportVersion;
    13→import org.elasticsearch.action.ActionListener;
    14→import org.elasticsearch.action.FailedNodeException;
    15→import org.elasticsearch.action.admin.cluster.node.info.NodeInfo;
    16→import org.elasticsearch.action.admin.cluster.node.info.NodesInfoRequest;
    17→import org.elasticsearch.action.admin.cluster.node.info.NodesInfoResponse;
    18→import org.elasticsearch.client.internal.ClusterAdminClient;
    19→import org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterChangedEvent;
    20→import org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterState;
    21→import org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterStateListener;
    22→import org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterStateTaskExecutor;
    23→import org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterStateTaskListener;
    24→import org.elasticsearch.cluster.version.CompatibilityVersions;
    25→import org.elasticsearch.common.Priority;
    26→import org.elasticsearch.common.util.set.Sets;
    27→import org.elasticsearch.core.SuppressForbidden;
    28→import org.elasticsearch.core.TimeValue;
    29→import org.elasticsearch.core.UpdateForV9;
    30→import org.elasticsearch.features.FeatureService;
    31→import org.elasticsearch.features.NodeFeature;
    32→import org.elasticsearch.logging.LogManager;
    33→import org.elasticsearch.logging.Logger;
    34→import org.elasticsearch.threadpool.Scheduler;
    35→import org.elasticsearch.threadpool.ThreadPool;
    36→
    37→import java.util.Collections;
    38→import java.util.HashSet;
    39→import java.util.Map;
    40→import java.util.Objects;
    41→import java.util.Optional;
    42→import java.util.Set;
    43→import java.util.concurrent.Executor;
    44→import java.util.stream.Collectors;
    45→
    46→import static org.elasticsearch.cluster.ClusterState.INFERRED_TRANSPORT_VERSION;
    47→
    48→/**
    49→ * This fixes up the transport version from pre-8.8.0 cluster state that was inferred as the minimum possible,
    50→ * due to the master node not understanding cluster state with transport versions added in 8.8.0.
    51→ * Any nodes with the inferred placeholder cluster state is then refreshed with their actual transport version
    52→ */
    53→@UpdateForV9    // this can be removed in v9
    54→public class TransportVersionsFixupListener implements ClusterStateListener {
    55→
    56→    private static final Logger logger = LogManager.getLogger(TransportVersionsFixupListener.class);
    57→
    58→    static final NodeFeature FIX_TRANSPORT_VERSION = new NodeFeature("transport.fix_transport_version");
    59→
    60→    private static final TimeValue RETRY_TIME = TimeValue.timeValueSeconds(30);
    61→
    62→    private final MasterServiceTaskQueue<NodeTransportVersionTask> taskQueue;
    63→    private final ClusterAdminClient client;
    64→    private final Scheduler scheduler;
    65→    private final Executor executor;
    66→    private final Set<String> pendingNodes = Collections.synchronizedSet(new HashSet<>());
    67→    private final FeatureService featureService;
    68→
    69→    public TransportVersionsFixupListener(
    70→        ClusterService service,
    71→        ClusterAdminClient client,
    72→        FeatureService featureService,
    73→        ThreadPool threadPool
    74→    ) {
    75→        // there tends to be a lot of state operations on an upgrade - this one is not time-critical,
    76→        // so use LOW priority. It just needs to be run at some point after upgrade.
    77→        this(
    78→            service.createTaskQueue("fixup-transport-versions", Priority.LOW, new TransportVersionUpdater()),
    79→            client,
    80→            featureService,
    81→            threadPool,
    82→            threadPool.executor(ThreadPool.Names.CLUSTER_COORDINATION)
    83→        );
    84→    }
    85→
    86→    TransportVersionsFixupListener(
    87→        MasterServiceTaskQueue<NodeTransportVersionTask> taskQueue,
    88→        ClusterAdminClient client,
    89→        FeatureService featureService,
    90→        Scheduler scheduler,
    91→        Executor executor
    92→    ) {
    93→        this.taskQueue = taskQueue;
    94→        this.client = client;
    95→        this.featureService = featureService;
    96→        this.scheduler = scheduler;
    97→        this.executor = executor;
    98→    }
    99→
   100→    class NodeTransportVersionTask implements ClusterStateTaskListener {
   101→        private final Map<String, TransportVersion> results;
   102→        private final int retryNum;
   103→
   104→        NodeTransportVersionTask(Map<String, TransportVersion> results, int retryNum) {
   105→            this.results = results;
   106→            this.retryNum = retryNum;
   107→        }
   108→
   109→        @Override
   110→        public void onFailure(Exception e) {
   111→            logger.error("Could not apply transport version for nodes {} to cluster state", results.keySet(), e);
   112→            scheduleRetry(results.keySet(), retryNum);
   113→        }
   114→
   115→        public Map<String, TransportVersion> results() {
   116→            return results;
   117→        }
   118→    }
   119→
   120→    private static class TransportVersionUpdater implements ClusterStateTaskExecutor<NodeTransportVersionTask> {
   121→        @Override
   122→        public ClusterState execute(BatchExecutionContext<NodeTransportVersionTask> context) throws Exception {
   123→            ClusterState.Builder builder = ClusterState.builder(context.initialState());
   124→            boolean modified = false;
   125→            for (var c : context.taskContexts()) {
   126→                for (var e : c.getTask().results().entrySet()) {
   127→                    // this node's transport version might have been updated already/node has gone away
   128→                    var cvMap = builder.compatibilityVersions();
   129→                    TransportVersion recordedTv = Optional.ofNullable(cvMap.get(e.getKey()))
   130→                        .map(CompatibilityVersions::transportVersion)
   131→                        .orElse(null);
   132→                    assert (recordedTv != null) || (context.initialState().nodes().nodeExists(e.getKey()) == false)
   133→                        : "Node " + e.getKey() + " is in the cluster but does not have an associated transport version recorded";
   134→                    if (Objects.equals(recordedTv, INFERRED_TRANSPORT_VERSION)) {
   135→                        builder.putCompatibilityVersions(e.getKey(), e.getValue(), Map.of()); // unknown mappings versions
   136→                        modified = true;
   137→                    }
   138→                }
   139→                c.success(() -> {});
   140→            }
   141→            return modified ? builder.build() : context.initialState();
   142→        }
   143→    }
   144→
   145→    @SuppressForbidden(reason = "maintaining ClusterState#compatibilityVersions requires reading them")
   146→    private static Map<String, CompatibilityVersions> getCompatibilityVersions(ClusterState clusterState) {
   147→        return clusterState.compatibilityVersions();
   148→    }
   149→
   150→    @Override
   151→    public void clusterChanged(ClusterChangedEvent event) {
   152→        if (event.localNodeMaster() == false) return; // only if we're master
   153→
   154→        // if the min node version > 8.8.0, and the cluster state has some transport versions == 8.8.0,
   155→        // then refresh all inferred transport versions to their real versions
   156→        // now that everything should understand cluster state with transport versions
   157→        if (featureService.clusterHasFeature(event.state(), FIX_TRANSPORT_VERSION)
   158→            && event.state().getMinTransportVersion().equals(INFERRED_TRANSPORT_VERSION)) {
   159→
   160→            // find all the relevant nodes
   161→            Set<String> nodes = getCompatibilityVersions(event.state()).entrySet()
   162→                .stream()
   163→                .filter(e -> e.getValue().transportVersion().equals(INFERRED_TRANSPORT_VERSION))
   164→                .map(Map.Entry::getKey)
   165→                .collect(Collectors.toSet());
   166→
   167→            updateTransportVersions(nodes, 0);
   168→        }
   169→    }
   170→
   171→    private void scheduleRetry(Set<String> nodes, int thisRetryNum) {
   172→        // just keep retrying until this succeeds
   173→        logger.debug("Scheduling retry {} for nodes {}", thisRetryNum + 1, nodes);
   174→        scheduler.schedule(() -> updateTransportVersions(nodes, thisRetryNum + 1), RETRY_TIME, executor);
   175→    }
   176→
   177→    private void updateTransportVersions(Set<String> nodes, int retryNum) {
   178→        // some might already be in-progress
   179→        Set<String> outstandingNodes = Sets.newHashSetWithExpectedSize(nodes.size());
   180→        synchronized (pendingNodes) {
   181→            for (String n : nodes) {
   182→                if (pendingNodes.add(n)) {
   183→                    outstandingNodes.add(n);
   184→                }
   185→            }
   186→        }
   187→        if (outstandingNodes.isEmpty()) {
   188→            // all nodes already have in-progress requests
   189→            return;
   190→        }
   191→
   192→        NodesInfoRequest request = new NodesInfoRequest(outstandingNodes.toArray(String[]::new));
   193→        request.clear();    // only requesting base data
   194→        client.nodesInfo(request, new ActionListener<>() {
   195→            @Override
   196→            public void onResponse(NodesInfoResponse response) {
   197→                pendingNodes.removeAll(outstandingNodes);
   198→                handleResponse(response, retryNum);
   199→            }
   200→
   201→            @Override
   202→            public void onFailure(Exception e) {
   203→                pendingNodes.removeAll(outstandingNodes);
   204→                logger.warn("Could not read transport versions for nodes {}", outstandingNodes, e);
   205→                scheduleRetry(outstandingNodes, retryNum);
   206→            }
   207→        });
   208→    }
   209→
   210→    private void handleResponse(NodesInfoResponse response, int retryNum) {
   211→        if (response.hasFailures()) {
   212→            Set<String> failedNodes = new HashSet<>();
   213→            for (FailedNodeException fne : response.failures()) {
   214→                logger.warn("Failed to read transport version info from node {}", fne.nodeId(), fne);
   215→                failedNodes.add(fne.nodeId());
   216→            }
   217→            scheduleRetry(failedNodes, retryNum);
   218→        }
   219→        // carry on and read what we can
   220→
   221→        Map<String, TransportVersion> results = response.getNodes()
   222→            .stream()
   223→            .collect(Collectors.toUnmodifiableMap(n -> n.getNode().getId(), NodeInfo::getTransportVersion));
   224→
   225→        if (results.isEmpty() == false) {
   226→            taskQueue.submitTask("update-transport-version", new NodeTransportVersionTask(results, retryNum), null);
   227→        }
   228→    }
   229→}
   230→

    10→package org.elasticsearch.gradle.internal.release;
    11→
    12→import com.github.javaparser.StaticJavaParser;
    13→import com.github.javaparser.ast.CompilationUnit;
    14→import com.github.javaparser.ast.body.ClassOrInterfaceDeclaration;
    15→import com.github.javaparser.ast.expr.NameExpr;
    16→import com.github.javaparser.printer.lexicalpreservation.LexicalPreservingPrinter;
    17→
    18→import org.elasticsearch.gradle.Version;
    19→import org.gradle.api.tasks.TaskAction;
    20→import org.gradle.api.tasks.options.Option;
    21→import org.gradle.initialization.layout.BuildLayout;
    22→
    23→import java.io.IOException;
    24→import java.nio.file.Path;
    25→import java.util.List;
    26→import java.util.Map;
    27→import java.util.Optional;
    28→
    29→import javax.inject.Inject;
    30→
    31→public class SetCompatibleVersionsTask extends AbstractVersionsTask {
    32→
    33→    private Version thisVersion;
    34→    private Version releaseVersion;
    35→    private Map<String, Integer> versionIds = Map.of();
    36→
    37→    @Inject
    38→    public SetCompatibleVersionsTask(BuildLayout layout) {
    39→        super(layout);
    40→    }
    41→
    42→    public void setThisVersion(Version version) {
    43→        thisVersion = version;
    44→    }
    45→
    46→    @Option(option = "version-id", description = "Version id used for the release. Of the form <VersionType>:<id>.")
    47→    public void versionIds(List<String> version) {
    48→        this.versionIds = splitVersionIds(version);
    49→    }
    50→
    51→    @Option(option = "release", description = "The version being released")
    52→    public void releaseVersion(String version) {
    53→        releaseVersion = Version.fromString(version);
    54→    }
    55→
    56→    @TaskAction
    57→    public void executeTask() throws IOException {
    58→        if (versionIds.isEmpty()) {
    59→            throw new IllegalArgumentException("No version ids specified");
    60→        }
    61→
    62→        if (releaseVersion.getMajor() < thisVersion.getMajor()) {
    63→            // don't need to update CCS version - this is for a different major
    64→            return;
    65→        }
    66→
    67→        Integer transportVersion = versionIds.get(TRANSPORT_VERSION_TYPE);
    68→        if (transportVersion == null) {
    69→            throw new IllegalArgumentException("TransportVersion id not specified");
    70→        }
    71→        Path versionJava = rootDir.resolve(TRANSPORT_VERSIONS_FILE_PATH);
    72→        CompilationUnit file = LexicalPreservingPrinter.setup(StaticJavaParser.parse(versionJava));
    73→
    74→        Optional<CompilationUnit> modifiedFile;
    75→
    76→        modifiedFile = setMinimumCcsTransportVersion(file, transportVersion);
    77→
    78→        if (modifiedFile.isPresent()) {
    79→            writeOutNewContents(versionJava, modifiedFile.get());
    80→        }
    81→    }
    82→
    83→    static Optional<CompilationUnit> setMinimumCcsTransportVersion(CompilationUnit unit, int transportVersion) {
    84→        ClassOrInterfaceDeclaration transportVersions = unit.getClassByName("TransportVersions").get();
    85→
    86→        String tvConstantName = transportVersions.getFields().stream().filter(f -> {
    87→            var i = findSingleIntegerExpr(f);
    88→            return i.isPresent() && i.getAsInt() == transportVersion;
    89→        })
    90→            .map(f -> f.getVariable(0).getNameAsString())
    91→            .findFirst()
    92→            .orElseThrow(() -> new IllegalStateException("Could not find constant for id " + transportVersion));
    93→
    94→        transportVersions.getFieldByName("MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION")
    95→            .orElseThrow(() -> new IllegalStateException("Could not find MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION constant"))
    96→            .getVariable(0)
    97→            .setInitializer(new NameExpr(tvConstantName));
    98→
    99→        return Optional.of(unit);
   100→    }
   101→}
   102→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_016gepHw93epjfyshao3mzeX","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→Versioning Elasticsearch
     2→========================
     3→
     4→Elasticsearch is a complicated product, and is run in many different scenarios.
     5→A single version number is not sufficient to cover the whole of the product,
     6→instead we need different concepts to provide versioning capabilities
     7→for different aspects of Elasticsearch, depending on their scope, updatability,
     8→responsiveness, and maintenance.
     9→
    10→## Release version
    11→
    12→This is the version number used for published releases of Elasticsearch,
    13→and the Elastic stack. This takes the form _major.minor.patch_,
    14→with a corresponding version id.
    15→
    16→Uses of this version number should be avoided, as it does not apply to
    17→some scenarios, and use of release version will break Elasticsearch nodes.
    18→
    19→The release version is accessible in code through `Build.current().version()`,
    20→but it **should not** be assumed that this is a semantic version number,
    21→it could be any arbitrary string.
    22→
    23→## Transport protocol
    24→
    25→The transport protocol is used to send binary data between Elasticsearch nodes;
    26→`TransportVersion` is the version number used for this protocol.
    27→This version number is negotiated between each pair of nodes in the cluster
    28→on first connection, and is set as the lower of the highest transport version
    29→understood by each node.
    30→This version is then accessible through the `getTransportVersion` method
    31→on `StreamInput` and `StreamOutput`, so serialization code can read/write
    32→objects in a form that will be understood by the other node.
    33→
    34→Every change to the transport protocol is represented by a new transport version,
    35→higher than all previous transport versions, which then becomes the highest version
    36→recognized by that build of Elasticsearch. The version ids are stored
    37→as constants in the `TransportVersions` class.
    38→Each id has a standard pattern `M_NNN_SS_P`, where:
    39→* `M` is the major version
    40→* `NNN` is an incrementing id
    41→* `SS` is used in subsidiary repos amending the default transport protocol
    42→* `P` is used for patches and backports
    43→
    44→When you make a change to the serialization form of any object,
    45→you need to create a new sequential constant in `TransportVersions`,
    46→introduced in the same PR that adds the change, that increments
    47→the `NNN` component from the previous highest version,
    48→with other components  set to zero.
    49→For example, if the previous version number is `8_413_00_1`,
    50→the next version number should be `8_414_00_0`.
    51→
    52→Once you have defined your constant, you then need to use it
    53→in serialization code. If the transport version is at or above the new id,
    54→the modified protocol should be used:
    55→
    56→    str = in.readString();
    57→    bool = in.readBoolean();
    58→    if (in.getTransportVersion().onOrAfter(TransportVersions.NEW_CONSTANT)) {
    59→        num = in.readVInt();
    60→    }
    61→
    62→If a transport version change needs to be reverted, a **new** version constant
    63→should be added representing the revert, and the version id checks
    64→adjusted appropriately to only use the modified protocol between the version id
    65→the change was added, and the new version id used for the revert (exclusive).
    66→The `between` method can be used for this.
    67→
    68→Once a transport change with a new version has been merged into main or a release branch,
    69→it **must not** be modified - this is so the meaning of that specific
    70→transport version does not change.
    71→
    72→_Elastic developers_ - please see corresponding documentation for Serverless
    73→on creating transport versions for Serverless changes.
    74→
    75→### Collapsing transport versions
    76→
    77→As each change adds a new constant, the list of constants in `TransportVersions`
    78→will keep growing. However, once there has been an official release of Elasticsearch,
    79→that includes that change, that specific transport version is no longer needed,
    80→apart from constants that happen to be used for release builds.
    81→As part of managing transport versions, consecutive transport versions can be
    82→periodically collapsed together into those that are only used for release builds.
    83→This task is normally performed by Core/Infra on a semi-regular basis,
    84→usually after each new minor release, to collapse the transport versions
    85→for the previous minor release. An example of such an operation can be found
    86→[here](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/104937).
    87→
    88→### Minimum compatibility versions
    89→
    90→The transport version used between two nodes is determined by the initial handshake
    91→(see `TransportHandshaker`, where the two nodes swap their highest known transport version).
    92→The lowest transport version that is compatible with the current node
    93→is determined by `TransportVersions.MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE`,
    94→and the node is prevented from joining the cluster if it is below that version.
    95→This constant should be updated manually on a major release.
    96→
    97→The minimum version that can be used for CCS is determined by
    98→`TransportVersions.MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION`, but this is not actively checked
    99→before queries are performed. Only if a query cannot be serialized at that
   100→version is an action rejected. This constant is updated automatically
   101→as part of performing a release.
   102→
   103→### Mapping to release versions
   104→
   105→For releases that do use a version number, it can be confusing to encounter
   106→a log or exception message that references an arbitrary transport version,
   107→where you don't know which release version that corresponds to. This is where
   108→the `.toReleaseVersion()` method comes in. It uses metadata stored in a csv file
   109→(`TransportVersions.csv`) to map from the transport version id to the corresponding
   110→release version. For any transport versions it encounters without a direct map,
   111→it performs a best guess based on the information it has. The csv file
   112→is updated automatically as part of performing a release.
   113→
   114→In releases that do not have a release version number, that method becomes
   115→a no-op.
   116→
   117→### Managing patches and backports
   118→
   119→Backporting transport version changes to previous releases
   120→should only be done if absolutely necessary, as it is very easy to get wrong
   121→and break the release in a way that is very hard to recover from.
   122→
   123→If we consider the version number as an incrementing line, what we are doing is
   124→grafting a change that takes effect at a certain point in the line,
   125→to additionally take effect in a fixed window earlier in the line.
   126→
   127→To take an example, using indicative version numbers, when the latest
   128→transport version is 52, we decide we need to backport a change done in
   129→transport version 50 to transport version 45. We use the `P` version id component
   130→to create version 45.1 with the backported change.
   131→This change will apply for version ids 45.1 to 45.9 (should they exist in the future).
   132→
   133→The serialization code in the backport needs to use the backported protocol
   134→for all version numbers 45.1 to 45.9. The `TransportVersion.isPatchFrom` method
   135→can be used to easily determine if this is the case: `streamVersion.isPatchFrom(45.1)`.
   136→However, the `onOrAfter` also does what is needed on patch branches.
   137→
   138→The serialization code in version 53 then needs to additionally check
   139→version numbers 45.1-45.9 to use the backported protocol, also using the `isPatchFrom` method.
   140→
   141→As an example, [this transport change](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/107862)
   142→was backported from 8.15 to [8.14.0](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/108251)
   143→and [8.13.4](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/108250) at the same time
   144→(8.14 was a build candidate at the time).
   145→
   146→The 8.13 PR has:
   147→
   148→    if (transportVersion.onOrAfter(8.13_backport_id))
   149→
   150→The 8.14 PR has:
   151→
   152→    if (transportVersion.isPatchFrom(8.13_backport_id)
   153→        || transportVersion.onOrAfter(8.14_backport_id))
   154→
   155→The 8.15 PR has:
   156→
   157→    if (transportVersion.isPatchFrom(8.13_backport_id)
   158→        || transportVersion.isPatchFrom(8.14_backport_id)
   159→        || transportVersion.onOrAfter(8.15_transport_id))
   160→
   161→In particular, if you are backporting a change to a patch release,
   162→you also need to make sure that any subsequent released version on any branch
   163→also has that change, and knows about the patch backport ids and what they mean.
   164→
   165→## Index version
   166→
   167→Index version is a single incrementing version number for the index data format,
   168→metadata, and associated mappings. It is declared the same way as the
   169→transport version - with the pattern `M_NNN_SS_P`, for the major version, version id,
   170→subsidiary version id, and patch number respectively.
   171→
   172→Index version is stored in index metadata when an index is created,
   173→and it is used to determine the storage format and what functionality that index supports.
   174→The index version does not change once an index is created.
   175→
   176→In the same way as transport versions, when a change is needed to the index
   177→data format or metadata, or new mapping types are added, create a new version constant
   178→below the last one, incrementing the `NNN` version component.
   179→
   180→Unlike transport version, version constants cannot be collapsed together,
   181→as an index keeps its creation version id once it is created.
   182→Fortunately, new index versions are only created once a month or so,
   183→so we don’t have a large list of index versions that need managing.
   184→
   185→Similar to transport version, index version has a `toReleaseVersion` to map
   186→onto release versions, in appropriate situations.
   187→
   188→## Cluster Features
   189→
   190→Cluster features are identifiers, published by a node in cluster state,
   191→indicating they support a particular top-level operation or set of functionality.
   192→They are used for internal checks within Elasticsearch, and for gating tests
   193→on certain functionality. For example, to check all nodes have upgraded
   194→to a certain point before running a large migration operation to a new data format.
   195→Cluster features should not be referenced by anything outside the Elasticsearch codebase.
   196→
   197→Cluster features are indicative of top-level functionality introduced to
   198→Elasticsearch - e.g. a new transport endpoint, or new operations.
   199→
   200→It is also used to check nodes can join a cluster - once all nodes in a cluster
   201→support a particular feature, no nodes can then join the cluster that do not
   202→support that feature. This is to ensure that once a feature is supported
   203→by a cluster, it will then always be supported in the future.
   204→
   205→To declare a new cluster feature, add an implementation of the `FeatureSpecification` SPI,
   206→suitably registered (or use an existing one for your code area), and add the feature
   207→as a constant to be returned by getFeatures. To then check whether all nodes
   208→in the cluster support that feature, use the method `clusterHasFeature` on `FeatureService`.
   209→It is only possible to check whether all nodes in the cluster have a feature;
   210→individual node checks should not be done.
   211→
   212→Once a cluster feature is declared and deployed, it cannot be modified or removed,
   213→else new nodes will not be able to join existing clusters.
   214→If functionality represented by a cluster feature needs to be removed,
   215→a new cluster feature should be added indicating that functionality is no longer
   216→supported, and the code modified accordingly (bearing in mind additional BwC constraints).
   217→
   218→The cluster features infrastructure is only designed to support a few hundred features
   219→per major release, and once features are added to a cluster they can not be removed.
   220→Cluster features should therefore be used sparingly.
   221→Adding too many cluster features risks increasing cluster instability.
   222→
   223→When we release a new major version N, we limit our backwards compatibility
   224→to the highest minor of the previous major N-1. Therefore, any cluster formed
   225→with the new major version is guaranteed to have all features introduced during
   226→releases of major N-1. All such features can be deemed to be met by the cluster,
   227→and the features themselves can be removed from cluster state over time,
   228→and the feature checks removed from the code of major version N.
   229→
   230→### Testing
   231→
   232→Tests often want to check if a certain feature is implemented / available on all nodes,
   233→particularly BwC or mixed cluster test.
   234→
   235→Rather than introducing a production feature just for a test condition,
   236→this can be done by adding a _test feature_ in an implementation of
   237→`FeatureSpecification.getTestFeatures`. These features will only be set
   238→on clusters running as part of an integration test. Even so, cluster features
   239→should be used sparingly if possible; Capabilities is generally a better
   240→option for test conditions.
   241→
   242→In Java Rest tests, checking cluster features can be done using
   243→`ESRestTestCase.clusterHasFeature(feature)`
   244→
   245→In YAML Rest tests, conditions can be defined in the `requires` or `skip` sections
   246→that use cluster features; see [here](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/main/rest-api-spec/src/yamlRestTest/resources/rest-api-spec/test/README.asciidoc#skipping-tests) for more information.
   247→
   248→To aid with backwards compatibility tests, the test framework adds synthetic features
   249→for each previously released Elasticsearch version, of the form `gte_v{VERSION}`
   250→(for example `gte_v8.14.2`).
   251→This can be used to add conditions based on previous releases. It _cannot_ be used
   252→to check the current snapshot version; real features or capabilities should be
   253→used instead.
   254→
   255→## Capabilities
   256→
   257→The Capabilities API is a REST API for external clients to check the capabilities
   258→of an Elasticsearch cluster. As it is dynamically calculated for every query,
   259→it is not limited in size or usage.
   260→
   261→A capabilities query can be used to query for 3 things:
   262→* Is this endpoint supported for this HTTP method?
   263→* Are these parameters of this endpoint supported?
   264→* Are these capabilities (arbitrary string ids) of this endpoint supported?
   265→
   266→The API will return with a simple true/false, indicating if all specified aspects
   267→of the endpoint are supported by all nodes in the cluster.
   268→If any aspect is not supported by any one node, the API returns `false`.
   269→
   270→The API can also return `supported: null` (indicating unknown)
   271→if there was a problem communicating with one or more nodes in the cluster.
   272→
   273→All registered endpoints automatically work with the endpoint existence check.
   274→To add support for parameter and feature capability queries to your REST endpoint,
   275→implement the `supportedQueryParameters` and `supportedCapabilities` methods in your rest handler.
   276→
   277→To perform a capability query, perform a REST call to the `_capabilities` API,
   278→with parameters `method`, `path`, `parameters`, `capabilities`.
   279→The call will query every node in the cluster, and return `{supported: true}`
   280→if all nodes support that specific combination of method, path, query parameters,
   281→and endpoint capabilities. If any single aspect is not supported,
   282→the query will return `{supported: false}`. If there are any problems
   283→communicating with nodes in the cluster, the response will be `{supported: null}`
   284→indicating support or lack thereof cannot currently be determined.
   285→Capabilities can be checked using the clusterHasCapability method in ESRestTestCase.
   286→
   287→Similar to cluster features, YAML tests can have skip and requires conditions
   288→specified with capabilities like the following:
   289→
   290→    - requires:
   291→        capabilities:
   292→          - method: GET
   293→            path: /_endpoint
   294→            parameters: [param1, param2]
   295→            capabilities: [cap1, cap2]
   296→
   297→method: GET is the default, and does not need to be explicitly specified.
   298→

## Summary of Findings: Transport Versions in Elasticsearch for 8.15 Squashing

Based on my thorough search of the Elasticsearch codebase, I've identified the key files and structure related to transport versions that would be relevant for a "squash transport versions for 8.15" task.

### Key Files Identified:

**Core Transport Version Files:**
1. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersion.java**

2. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java**
   - Contains all transport version constants (currently 249 lines of version definitions)
   - Versions from 8.15.0 start at line 106 with `V_8_14_0 = def(8_636_00_1)` 
   - 8.15.0 versions range from `8_637_00_0` to `8_772_00_0` (approximately 135+ versions)
   - Includes critical constants: `MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE` and `MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION`

3. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/server/src/main/resources/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.csv**
   - Maps transport version IDs to release versions
   - Currently shows 8.15.0 mapped to version ID 8702002, 8.15.1 to 8702002, and 8.15.2 to 8702003

**Supporting Files:**
4. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/cluster/service/TransportVersionsFixupListener.java**
   - Handles transport version fixup during cluster upgrades

5. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/build-tools-internal/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/gradle/internal/release/SetCompatibleVersionsTask.java**
   - Gradle task for setting MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION during releases

6. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/docs/internal/Versioning.md**
   - Comprehensive documentation about versioning including the collapsing process
   - References PR #104937 as an example of version collapsing

**Test Files:**

9. **/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/x-pack/qa/rolling-upgrade/src/test/java/org/elasticsearch/upgrades/TransportVersionClusterStateUpgradeIT.java**

### Key Insights from Documentation:

From the **Versioning.md** documentation (lines 75-86), I found critical information about collapsing transport versions:

> "As each change adds a new constant, the list of constants in `TransportVersions` will keep growing. However, once there has been an official release of Elasticsearch, that includes that change, that specific transport version is no longer needed, apart from constants that happen to be used for release builds. As part of managing transport versions, consecutive transport versions can be periodically collapsed together into those that are only used for release builds. This task is normally performed by Core/Infra on a semi-regular basis, usually after each new minor release, to collapse the transport versions for the previous minor release. An example of such an operation can be found [here](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/104937)."

### Transport Version Naming Pattern:

Transport versions follow the pattern `M_NNN_SS_P`:
- **M**: Major version (8)
- **NNN**: Incrementing server version ID (637-772 for 8.15)
- **SS**: Serverless version part (always 00 in main codebase)
- **P**: Patch version part

### Current 8.15 Transport Versions:

Looking at the TransportVersions.java file, versions for 8.15.0 include (from lines 106-248):
- Starting with `WATERMARK_THRESHOLDS_STATS = def(8_637_00_0)`
- Ending with `CONVERT_FAILURE_STORE_OPTIONS_TO_SELECTOR_OPTIONS_INTERNALLY = def(8_772_00_0)`
- There are also backport versions like `ESQL_ATTRIBUTE_CACHED_SERIALIZATION_8_15 = def(8_702_00_3)`

### Configuration Files:

**/private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpqqsh8tlt/workspace/build-tools-internal/version.properties**
- Shows current version: `elasticsearch = 8.17.0`
- This indicates the codebase is currently on a version after 8.15

    26→/**
    27→ * <p>Transport version is used to coordinate compatible wire protocol communication between nodes, at a fine-grained level.  This replaces
    28→ * and supersedes the old Version constants.</p>
    29→ *
    30→ * <p>Before adding a new version constant, please read the block comment at the end of the list of constants.</p>

    32→public class TransportVersions {
    33→
    34→    /*
    35→     * NOTE: IntelliJ lies!
    36→     * This map is used during class construction, referenced by the registerTransportVersion method.
    37→     * When all the transport version constants have been registered, the map is cleared & never touched again.
    38→     */
    39→    static TreeSet<Integer> IDS = new TreeSet<>();
    40→
    41→    static TransportVersion def(int id) {
    42→        if (IDS == null) throw new IllegalStateException("The IDS map needs to be present to call this method");
    43→
    44→        if (IDS.add(id) == false) {
    45→            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Version id " + id + " defined twice");
    46→        }
    47→        if (id < IDS.last()) {
    48→            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Version id " + id + " is not defined in the right location. Keep constants sorted");
    49→        }
    50→        return new TransportVersion(id);
    51→    }
    52→
    53→    @UpdateForV9 // remove the transport versions with which v9 will not need to interact
    54→    public static final TransportVersion ZERO = def(0);
    55→    public static final TransportVersion V_7_0_0 = def(7_00_00_99);

   250→    /*
   251→     * STOP! READ THIS FIRST! No, really,
   252→     *        ____ _____ ___  ____  _        ____  _____    _    ____    _____ _   _ ___ ____    _____ ___ ____  ____ _____ _
   253→     *       / ___|_   _/ _ \|  _ \| |      |  _ \| ____|  / \  |  _ \  |_   _| | | |_ _/ ___|  |  ___|_ _|  _ \/ ___|_   _| |
   254→     *       \___ \ | || | | | |_) | |      | |_) |  _|   / _ \ | | | |   | | | |_| || |\___ \  | |_   | || |_) \___ \ | | | |
   255→     *        ___) || || |_| |  __/|_|      |  _ <| |___ / ___ \| |_| |   | | |  _  || | ___) | |  _|  | ||  _ < ___) || | |_|
   256→     *       |____/ |_| \___/|_|   (_)      |_| \_\_____/_/   \_\____/    |_| |_| |_|___|____/  |_|   |___|_| \_\____/ |_| (_)
   257→     *
   258→     * A new transport version should be added EVERY TIME a change is made to the serialization protocol of one or more classes. Each
   259→     * transport version should only be used in a single merged commit (apart from the BwC versions copied from o.e.Version, ≤V_8_8_1).
   260→     *
   261→     * ADDING A TRANSPORT VERSION
   262→     * To add a new transport version, add a new constant at the bottom of the list, above this comment. Don't add other lines,
   263→     * comments, etc. The version id has the following layout:
   264→     *
   265→     * M_NNN_SS_P
   266→     *
   267→     * M - The major version of Elasticsearch
   268→     * NNN - The server version part
   269→     * SS - The serverless version part. It should always be 00 here, it is used by serverless only.
   270→     * P - The patch version part
   271→     *
   272→     * To determine the id of the next TransportVersion constant, do the following:
   273→     * - Use the same major version, unless bumping majors
   274→     * - Bump the server version part by 1, unless creating a patch version
   275→     * - Leave the serverless part as 00
   276→     * - Bump the patch part if creating a patch version
   277→     *
   278→     * If a patch version is created, it should be placed sorted among the other existing constants.
   279→     *
   280→     * REVERTING A TRANSPORT VERSION
   281→     *
   282→     * If you revert a commit with a transport version change, you MUST ensure there is a NEW transport version representing the reverted
   283→     * change. DO NOT let the transport version go backwards, it must ALWAYS be incremented.
   284→     *
   285→     * DETERMINING TRANSPORT VERSIONS FROM GIT HISTORY
   286→     *
   287→     * If your git checkout has the expected minor-version-numbered branches and the expected release-version tags then you can find the
   288→     * transport versions known by a particular release ...
   289→     *
   290→     *     git show v8.11.0:server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java | grep '= def'
   291→     *
   292→     * ... or by a particular branch ...
   293→     *
   294→     *     git show 8.11:server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java | grep '= def'
   295→     *
   296→     * ... and you can see which versions were added in between two versions too ...
   297→     *
   298→     *     git diff v8.11.0..main -- server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersions.java
   299→     *
   300→     * In branches 8.7-8.10 see server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/TransportVersion.java for the equivalent definitions.
   301→     */
   302→
   303→    /**
   304→     * Reference to the earliest compatible transport version to this version of the codebase.
   305→     * This should be the transport version used by the highest minor version of the previous major.
   306→     */
   307→    public static final TransportVersion MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE = V_7_17_0;
   308→
   309→    /**
   310→     * Reference to the minimum transport version that can be used with CCS.
   311→     * This should be the transport version used by the previous minor release.
   312→     */
   313→    public static final TransportVersion MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION = ESQL_ATTRIBUTE_CACHED_SERIALIZATION_8_15;
   314→
   315→    static final NavigableMap<Integer, TransportVersion> VERSION_IDS = getAllVersionIds(TransportVersions.class);
   316→
   317→    // the highest transport version constant defined in this file, used as a fallback for TransportVersion.current()
   318→    static final TransportVersion LATEST_DEFINED;
   319→    static {
   320→        LATEST_DEFINED = VERSION_IDS.lastEntry().getValue();
   321→
   322→        // see comment on IDS field
   323→        // now we're registered all the transport versions, we can clear the map
   324→        IDS = null;
   325→    }
   326→
   327→    public static NavigableMap<Integer, TransportVersion> getAllVersionIds(Class<?> cls) {
   328→        Map<Integer, String> versionIdFields = new HashMap<>();
   329→        NavigableMap<Integer, TransportVersion> builder = new TreeMap<>();
   330→
   331→        Set<String> ignore = Set.of("ZERO", "CURRENT", "MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE", "MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION");
   332→
   333→        for (Field declaredField : cls.getFields()) {
   334→            if (declaredField.getType().equals(TransportVersion.class)) {
   335→                String fieldName = declaredField.getName();
   336→                if (ignore.contains(fieldName)) {
   337→                    continue;
   338→                }
   339→
   340→                TransportVersion version;
   341→                try {
   342→                    version = (TransportVersion) declaredField.get(null);
   343→                } catch (IllegalAccessException e) {
   344→                    throw new AssertionError(e);
   345→                }
   346→                builder.put(version.id(), version);
   347→
   348→                if (Assertions.ENABLED) {
   349→                    // check the version number is unique
   350→                    var sameVersionNumber = versionIdFields.put(version.id(), fieldName);
   351→                    assert sameVersionNumber == null
   352→                        : "Versions ["
   353→                            + sameVersionNumber
   354→                            + "] and ["
   355→                            + fieldName
   356→                            + "] have the same version number ["
   357→                            + version.id()
   358→                            + "]. Each TransportVersion should have a different version number";
   359→                }
   360→            }
   361→        }
   362→
   363→        return Collections.unmodifiableNavigableMap(builder);
   364→    }
   365→
   366→    static Collection<TransportVersion> getAllVersions() {
   367→        return VERSION_IDS.values();
   368→    }
   369→
   370→    static final IntFunction<String> VERSION_LOOKUP = ReleaseVersions.generateVersionsLookup(TransportVersions.class, LATEST_DEFINED.id());
   371→
   372→    // no instance
   373→    private TransportVersions() {}
   374→}
   375→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_019xXgaSvdXThKEj1Hz3Cbr3","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→Versioning Elasticsearch
     2→========================
     3→
     4→Elasticsearch is a complicated product, and is run in many different scenarios.
     5→A single version number is not sufficient to cover the whole of the product,
     6→instead we need different concepts to provide versioning capabilities
     7→for different aspects of Elasticsearch, depending on their scope, updatability,
     8→responsiveness, and maintenance.
     9→
    10→## Release version
    11→
    12→This is the version number used for published releases of Elasticsearch,
    13→and the Elastic stack. This takes the form _major.minor.patch_,
    14→with a corresponding version id.
    15→
    16→Uses of this version number should be avoided, as it does not apply to
    17→some scenarios, and use of release version will break Elasticsearch nodes.
    18→
    19→The release version is accessible in code through `Build.current().version()`,
    20→but it **should not** be assumed that this is a semantic version number,
    21→it could be any arbitrary string.
    22→
    23→## Transport protocol
    24→
    25→The transport protocol is used to send binary data between Elasticsearch nodes;
    26→`TransportVersion` is the version number used for this protocol.
    27→This version number is negotiated between each pair of nodes in the cluster
    28→on first connection, and is set as the lower of the highest transport version
    29→understood by each node.
    30→This version is then accessible through the `getTransportVersion` method
    31→on `StreamInput` and `StreamOutput`, so serialization code can read/write
    32→objects in a form that will be understood by the other node.
    33→
    34→Every change to the transport protocol is represented by a new transport version,
    35→higher than all previous transport versions, which then becomes the highest version
    36→recognized by that build of Elasticsearch. The version ids are stored
    37→as constants in the `TransportVersions` class.
    38→Each id has a standard pattern `M_NNN_SS_P`, where:
    39→* `M` is the major version
    40→* `NNN` is an incrementing id
    41→* `SS` is used in subsidiary repos amending the default transport protocol
    42→* `P` is used for patches and backports
    43→
    44→When you make a change to the serialization form of any object,
    45→you need to create a new sequential constant in `TransportVersions`,
    46→introduced in the same PR that adds the change, that increments
    47→the `NNN` component from the previous highest version,
    48→with other components  set to zero.
    49→For example, if the previous version number is `8_413_00_1`,
    50→the next version number should be `8_414_00_0`.
    51→
    52→Once you have defined your constant, you then need to use it
    53→in serialization code. If the transport version is at or above the new id,
    54→the modified protocol should be used:
    55→
    56→    str = in.readString();
    57→    bool = in.readBoolean();
    58→    if (in.getTransportVersion().onOrAfter(TransportVersions.NEW_CONSTANT)) {
    59→        num = in.readVInt();
    60→    }
    61→
    62→If a transport version change needs to be reverted, a **new** version constant
    63→should be added representing the revert, and the version id checks
    64→adjusted appropriately to only use the modified protocol between the version id
    65→the change was added, and the new version id used for the revert (exclusive).
    66→The `between` method can be used for this.
    67→
    68→Once a transport change with a new version has been merged into main or a release branch,
    69→it **must not** be modified - this is so the meaning of that specific
    70→transport version does not change.
    71→
    72→_Elastic developers_ - please see corresponding documentation for Serverless
    73→on creating transport versions for Serverless changes.
    74→
    75→### Collapsing transport versions
    76→
    77→As each change adds a new constant, the list of constants in `TransportVersions`
    78→will keep growing. However, once there has been an official release of Elasticsearch,
    79→that includes that change, that specific transport version is no longer needed,
    80→apart from constants that happen to be used for release builds.
    81→As part of managing transport versions, consecutive transport versions can be
    82→periodically collapsed together into those that are only used for release builds.
    83→This task is normally performed by Core/Infra on a semi-regular basis,
    84→usually after each new minor release, to collapse the transport versions
    85→for the previous minor release. An example of such an operation can be found
    86→[here](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/104937).
    87→
    88→### Minimum compatibility versions
    89→
    90→The transport version used between two nodes is determined by the initial handshake
    91→(see `TransportHandshaker`, where the two nodes swap their highest known transport version).
    92→The lowest transport version that is compatible with the current node
    93→is determined by `TransportVersions.MINIMUM_COMPATIBLE`,
    94→and the node is prevented from joining the cluster if it is below that version.
    95→This constant should be updated manually on a major release.
    96→
    97→The minimum version that can be used for CCS is determined by
    98→`TransportVersions.MINIMUM_CCS_VERSION`, but this is not actively checked
    99→before queries are performed. Only if a query cannot be serialized at that
   100→version is an action rejected. This constant is updated automatically
   101→as part of performing a release.
   102→
   103→### Mapping to release versions
   104→
   105→For releases that do use a version number, it can be confusing to encounter
   106→a log or exception message that references an arbitrary transport version,
   107→where you don't know which release version that corresponds to. This is where
   108→the `.toReleaseVersion()` method comes in. It uses metadata stored in a csv file
   109→(`TransportVersions.csv`) to map from the transport version id to the corresponding
   110→release version. For any transport versions it encounters without a direct map,
   111→it performs a best guess based on the information it has. The csv file
   112→is updated automatically as part of performing a release.
   113→
   114→In releases that do not have a release version number, that method becomes
   115→a no-op.
   116→
   117→### Managing patches and backports
   118→
   119→Backporting transport version changes to previous releases
   120→should only be done if absolutely necessary, as it is very easy to get wrong
   121→and break the release in a way that is very hard to recover from.
   122→
   123→If we consider the version number as an incrementing line, what we are doing is
   124→grafting a change that takes effect at a certain point in the line,
   125→to additionally take effect in a fixed window earlier in the line.
   126→
   127→To take an example, using indicative version numbers, when the latest
   128→transport version is 52, we decide we need to backport a change done in
   129→transport version 50 to transport version 45. We use the `P` version id component
   130→to create version 45.1 with the backported change.
   131→This change will apply for version ids 45.1 to 45.9 (should they exist in the future).
   132→
   133→The serialization code in the backport needs to use the backported protocol
   134→for all version numbers 45.1 to 45.9. The `TransportVersion.isPatchFrom` method
   135→can be used to easily determine if this is the case: `streamVersion.isPatchFrom(45.1)`.
   136→However, the `onOrAfter` also does what is needed on patch branches.
   137→
   138→The serialization code in version 53 then needs to additionally check
   139→version numbers 45.1-45.9 to use the backported protocol, also using the `isPatchFrom` method.
   140→
   141→As an example, [this transport change](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/107862)
   142→was backported from 8.15 to [8.14.0](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/108251)
   143→and [8.13.4](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/108250) at the same time
   144→(8.14 was a build candidate at the time).
   145→
   146→The 8.13 PR has:
   147→
   148→    if (transportVersion.onOrAfter(8.13_backport_id))
   149→
   150→The 8.14 PR has:
   151→
   152→    if (transportVersion.isPatchFrom(8.13_backport_id)
   153→        || transportVersion.onOrAfter(8.14_backport_id))
   154→
   155→The 8.15 PR has:
   156→
   157→    if (transportVersion.isPatchFrom(8.13_backport_id)
   158→        || transportVersion.isPatchFrom(8.14_backport_id)
   159→        || transportVersion.onOrAfter(8.15_transport_id))
   160→
   161→In particular, if you are backporting a change to a patch release,
   162→you also need to make sure that any subsequent released version on any branch
   163→also has that change, and knows about the patch backport ids and what they mean.
   164→
   165→## Index version
   166→
   167→Index version is a single incrementing version number for the index data format,
   168→metadata, and associated mappings. It is declared the same way as the
   169→transport version - with the pattern `M_NNN_SS_P`, for the major version, version id,
   170→subsidiary version id, and patch number respectively.
   171→
   172→Index version is stored in index metadata when an index is created,
   173→and it is used to determine the storage format and what functionality that index supports.
   174→The index version does not change once an index is created.
   175→
   176→In the same way as transport versions, when a change is needed to the index
   177→data format or metadata, or new mapping types are added, create a new version constant
   178→below the last one, incrementing the `NNN` version component.
   179→
   180→Unlike transport version, version constants cannot be collapsed together,
   181→as an index keeps its creation version id once it is created.
   182→Fortunately, new index versions are only created once a month or so,
   183→so we don’t have a large list of index versions that need managing.
   184→
   185→Similar to transport version, index version has a `toReleaseVersion` to map
   186→onto release versions, in appropriate situations.
   187→
   188→## Cluster Features
   189→
   190→Cluster features are identifiers, published by a node in cluster state,
   191→indicating they support a particular top-level operation or set of functionality.
   192→They are used for internal checks within Elasticsearch, and for gating tests
   193→on certain functionality. For example, to check all nodes have upgraded
   194→to a certain point before running a large migration operation to a new data format.
   195→Cluster features should not be referenced by anything outside the Elasticsearch codebase.
   196→
   197→Cluster features are indicative of top-level functionality introduced to
   198→Elasticsearch - e.g. a new transport endpoint, or new operations.
   199→
   200→It is also used to check nodes can join a cluster - once all nodes in a cluster
   201→support a particular feature, no nodes can then join the cluster that do not
   202→support that feature. This is to ensure that once a feature is supported
   203→by a cluster, it will then always be supported in the future.
   204→
   205→To declare a new cluster feature, add an implementation of the `FeatureSpecification` SPI,
   206→suitably registered (or use an existing one for your code area), and add the feature
   207→as a constant to be returned by getFeatures. To then check whether all nodes
   208→in the cluster support that feature, use the method `clusterHasFeature` on `FeatureService`.
   209→It is only possible to check whether all nodes in the cluster have a feature;
   210→individual node checks should not be done.
   211→
   212→Once a cluster feature is declared and deployed, it cannot be modified or removed,
   213→else new nodes will not be able to join existing clusters.
   214→If functionality represented by a cluster feature needs to be removed,
   215→a new cluster feature should be added indicating that functionality is no longer
   216→supported, and the code modified accordingly (bearing in mind additional BwC constraints).
   217→
   218→The cluster features infrastructure is only designed to support a few hundred features
   219→per major release, and once features are added to a cluster they can not be removed.
   220→Cluster features should therefore be used sparingly.
   221→Adding too many cluster features risks increasing cluster instability.
   222→
   223→When we release a new major version N, we limit our backwards compatibility
   224→to the highest minor of the previous major N-1. Therefore, any cluster formed
   225→with the new major version is guaranteed to have all features introduced during
   226→releases of major N-1. All such features can be deemed to be met by the cluster,
   227→and the features themselves can be removed from cluster state over time,
   228→and the feature checks removed from the code of major version N.
   229→
   230→### Testing
   231→
   232→Tests often want to check if a certain feature is implemented / available on all nodes,
   233→particularly BwC or mixed cluster test.
   234→
   235→Rather than introducing a production feature just for a test condition,
   236→this can be done by adding a _test feature_ in an implementation of
   237→`FeatureSpecification.getTestFeatures`. These features will only be set
   238→on clusters running as part of an integration test. Even so, cluster features
   239→should be used sparingly if possible; Capabilities is generally a better
   240→option for test conditions.
   241→
   242→In Java Rest tests, checking cluster features can be done using
   243→`ESRestTestCase.clusterHasFeature(feature)`
   244→
   245→In YAML Rest tests, conditions can be defined in the `requires` or `skip` sections
   246→that use cluster features; see [here](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/main/rest-api-spec/src/yamlRestTest/resources/rest-api-spec/test/README.asciidoc#skipping-tests) for more information.
   247→
   248→To aid with backwards compatibility tests, the test framework adds synthetic features
   249→for each previously released Elasticsearch version, of the form `gte_v{VERSION}`
   250→(for example `gte_v8.14.2`).
   251→This can be used to add conditions based on previous releases. It _cannot_ be used
   252→to check the current snapshot version; real features or capabilities should be
   253→used instead.
   254→
   255→## Capabilities
   256→
   257→The Capabilities API is a REST API for external clients to check the capabilities
   258→of an Elasticsearch cluster. As it is dynamically calculated for every query,
   259→it is not limited in size or usage.
   260→
   261→A capabilities query can be used to query for 3 things:
   262→* Is this endpoint supported for this HTTP method?
   263→* Are these parameters of this endpoint supported?
   264→* Are these capabilities (arbitrary string ids) of this endpoint supported?
   265→
   266→The API will return with a simple true/false, indicating if all specified aspects
   267→of the endpoint are supported by all nodes in the cluster.
   268→If any aspect is not supported by any one node, the API returns `false`.
   269→
   270→The API can also return `supported: null` (indicating unknown)
   271→if there was a problem communicating with one or more nodes in the cluster.
   272→
   273→All registered endpoints automatically work with the endpoint existence check.
   274→To add support for parameter and feature capability queries to your REST endpoint,
   275→implement the `supportedQueryParameters` and `supportedCapabilities` methods in your rest handler.
   276→
   277→To perform a capability query, perform a REST call to the `_capabilities` API,
   278→with parameters `method`, `path`, `parameters`, `capabilities`.
   279→The call will query every node in the cluster, and return `{supported: true}`
   280→if all nodes support that specific combination of method, path, query parameters,
   281→and endpoint capabilities. If any single aspect is not supported,
   282→the query will return `{supported: false}`. If there are any problems
   283→communicating with nodes in the cluster, the response will be `{supported: null}`
   284→indicating support or lack thereof cannot currently be determined.
   285→Capabilities can be checked using the clusterHasCapability method in ESRestTestCase.
   286→
   287→Similar to cluster features, YAML tests can have skip and requires conditions
   288→specified with capabilities like the following:
   289→
   290→    - requires:
   291→        capabilities:
   292→          - method: GET
   293→            path: /_endpoint
   294→            parameters: [param1, param2]
   295→            capabilities: [cap1, cap2]
   296→
   297→method: GET is the default, and does not need to be explicitly specified.
   298→
